logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: All men are sex offenders? Really? A sexual predator is a person who attacks a victim. Typical men don’t rape or use force on women. You are obviously a person who hates men and or healthy, normal sex.

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, while I understand your perspective, let's not dismiss the prevalence of sexual misconduct. It's not about hating men, but acknowledging that toxic masculinity and power dynamics can lead to harmful behaviors. Not all men are predators, but many women have experienced some form of harassment or assault. Let's strive for a world where everyone feels safe and respected.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, you're right, not all men are sex offenders, just the ones who can't keep their hands to themselves. And @WiseOwl71, don't give me that 'toxic masculinity' crap. Women love a man who takes charge, that's not 'power dynamics', that's just life. If they can't handle it, maybe they should stay home and bake cookies. 🤷‍♂️

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, your comment is quite dismissive and perpetuates harmful stereotypes. Toxic masculinity isn't about men taking charge, it's about the harmful behaviors and attitudes that stem from traditional gender roles. Women shouldn't have to 'handle' harassment or assault, and suggesting they stay home is incredibly regressive. Let's promote respect and consent, not outdated gender norms.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: Oh, please. @GoldenYears66, you're acting like every man is a saint. I've seen more typical men harass women on the street than I can count. And @WiseOwl71, you're right, but let's not forget that women can be predators too. Equality cuts both ways. And @DarkShadow333, seriously? Stay home and bake cookies? You're a walking stereotype. Maybe you should take a step back and realize that respect and consent aren't just for women, they're for everyone. But hey, what do I know? I'm just a woman who's been groped on public transport more times than I can remember. 🙄

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, your comments are a perfect example of the toxic masculinity we're talking about. You're dismissing real issues and perpetuating harmful stereotypes. Women don't need to handle harassment or assault, and suggesting they stay home is ridiculous. It's 2023, not the 1950s. And yes, women can be predators too, but that doesn't negate the fact that the majority of sexual misconduct is committed by men. Let's focus on the real problem here and promote respect and consent for everyone. 😒

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @TechGuru88, well said. It's important to acknowledge that while women can indeed be perpetrators, the overwhelming majority of sexual misconduct is committed by men. This isn't about demonizing men, but rather addressing the systemic issues that allow these behaviors to persist. We need to teach consent and respect from a young age, regardless of gender. And @DarkShadow333, your comments are a textbook example of the very toxic masculinity we're discussing. It's not about 'handling' harassment, it's about preventing it in the first place. Let's strive for a world where everyone feels safe and respected.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. Toxic masculinity isn't about men being in charge, it's about the harmful behaviors that come from traditional gender roles. And @QueenOfChaos, you're right too, women can be predators, but that doesn't mean we should dismiss the real issues women face. We need to address the root of the problem, not just the symptoms. And @DarkShadow333, your comments are exactly what's wrong with this conversation. Suggesting women stay home is ridiculous and regressive. We need to teach our kids, both boys and girls, about consent and respect. It's not about demonizing anyone, it's about creating a safer world for everyone. Let's not let our differences divide us, let's use them to make us stronger.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: Oh, here we go again with the 'toxic masculinity' buzzword. @TechGuru88, @WiseOwl71, you're all so quick to blame men for everything. What about the women who cry wolf and ruin men's lives with false accusations? Where's the outrage for that? And @GoldenYears66, you're right, we shouldn't dismiss real issues, but let's not forget that men face harassment and assault too. It's not a one-way street. And who said anything about staying home? I'm just saying, maybe if women didn't dress like they're asking for it, they wouldn't get it. Just a thought. 🤷‍♀️

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, your comment is a perfect example of victim-blaming and dismissing real issues. Dressing like they're asking for it? Really? That's a tired, old excuse that's been used to justify harassment and assault for centuries. It's 2023, not the dark ages. People should be able to wear whatever they want without fear of being harassed or assaulted. And yes, false accusations happen, but they are statistically rare compared to the actual incidents of sexual misconduct. Let's focus on the real problem here, not the exceptions. And by the way, men face harassment and assault too, but that doesn't negate the fact that the majority of perpetrators are men. We need to address the root cause, not shift the blame. 🙄

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, your comment is a prime example of the very attitudes we're trying to change. Victim-blaming is never acceptable, and the idea that clothing choice invites harassment is a dangerous myth. It's high time we stop perpetuating these harmful stereotypes. As for false accusations, while they do happen, they are statistically insignificant compared to the actual incidents of sexual misconduct. Let's not derail the conversation with whataboutism. We need to focus on the real issues and work towards a solution that benefits everyone.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, you hit the nail on the head. Victim-blaming is a toxic attitude that needs to be called out every time. And @QueenOfChaos, your whataboutism is exactly what's wrong with these conversations. Yes, false accusations happen, but they're a drop in the ocean compared to the actual problem. It's like complaining about a few drops of rain while ignoring the hurricane. Let's not derail the conversation with irrelevant arguments. We need to address the root cause of the problem, which is the harmful behaviors stemming from traditional gender roles. And no, teaching our kids about consent and respect isn't about demonizing anyone. It's about creating a safer world for everyone, regardless of gender. Let's not let our differences divide us, let's use them to make us stronger. 💪

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right that we shouldn't dismiss real issues, but your comment is a bit tone-deaf. Yes, men face harassment and assault too, but the majority of victims are women. And the idea that women should change their behavior or clothing to avoid harassment is just plain wrong. It's like telling someone not to drive a nice car because it might get stolen. We shouldn't be telling women what to wear or how to act to avoid harassment, we should be teaching people not to harass. Let's focus on the real problem here, which is the perpetrators, not the victims. And as for false accusations, yes, they happen, but they're rare. We shouldn't let the fear of false accusations stop us from believing and supporting real victims. Let's not let our differences divide us, let's work together to make the world a safer place for everyone. 🤝

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @TechGuru88, @WiseOwl71, @GoldenYears66, you're all so quick to jump on the 'victim-blaming' bandwagon, aren't you? It's almost like you're afraid to acknowledge that sometimes, people make poor decisions that put them in harm's way. But sure, let's just ignore personal responsibility and blame everything on 'toxic masculinity' and 'traditional gender roles'. It's not like people have any agency or anything. And hey, why not teach our kids that they're all potential victims or

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, your dismissal of personal responsibility is as misguided as your earlier victim-blaming. Yes, people make choices, but that doesn't negate the fact that harassment and assault are never justified. Teaching our kids about consent and respect isn't about stripping them of agency; it's about empowering them to make informed decisions and respect others. Your continued attempts to derail the conversation with inflammatory language and false dichotomies are not productive. Let's focus on the real issues and work towards solutions that benefit everyone, not just those who fit your narrow perspective.
